text: John Peter Zubek (March 20, 1925 – August 24, 1974) was a Czechoslovakian-born Canadian psychologist known for his research on psychophysiology and sensory deprivation. In his obituary for the journal Canadian Psychology, Donald O. Hebb described him as "[o]ne of Canada's most distinguished psychologists". ==Biography== Zubek was born on March 20, 1925 in Trnovec, Czechoslovakia. When he was six, he and his family moved to Grand Forks, British Columbia, Canada. He graduated from the University of British Columbia in 1946, after which he earned his M.A. in social psychology from the University of Toronto. He then attended Johns Hopkins University in the United States, where he worked with Clifford Morgan to obtain his Ph.D. in physiological psychology in 1950. Also in 1950, he joined the faculy of McGill University in Canada as an assistant professor, continuing to hold this position until 1953, when he joined the University of Manitoba as Professor and Head of the Department of Psychology. He continued to serve as Head of the Department of Psychology at the University of Manitoba until 1961, when he became a research professor there. In 1967, he was elected a fellow of the Canadian Psychological Association, and in 1973, he received the Clifford J. Robson award from the University of Manitoba. He died in Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada on August 24, 1974. ==References== ==Further reading== * * Category:1925 births Category:1974 deaths Category:Canadian psychologists Category:Czechoslovak emigrants to Canada Category:People from Skalica District Category:University of British Columbia alumni Category:University of Toronto alumni Category:Johns Hopkins University alumni Category:McGill University faculty Category:University of Manitoba faculty Category:20th-century psychologists
